docs.lead_paragraph: They are known as gatekeepers, and they are what many Americans dislike most about their health maintenance organizations. They are the primary-care doctors who must say yes before a patient can see a specialist. Mike Shoemaker, a Phoenix businessman, hated the requirement. He remembers when his wife was advised to consult a series of stomach specialists but had to go back to a primary-care doctor each time for permission.

headline.main: Many H.M.O.'s Easing Rules On Seeking Specialists' Care

docs.abstract: Many Americans complain that their health maintenance organization requires them to see primary-care doctor, or 'gatekeeper,' before they can see specialist; Phoenix businessman Mike Shoemaker recently switched his company's 28 employees to HMO that allows visits to specialists without such approval; many other people are demanding same freedom, and they are getting it from growing number of HMO's; some HMO's are charging more for plans that allow visits to specialists without prior permission; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: YOU'D THINK THE MAJORITY LEADER OF THE UNITED States Senate would have better things to do. But Trent Lott likes order so much that he often irons his cotton shirts after they have come back from the cleaners to remove any remaining wrinkles. ''He criticized the way I ironed shirts one day,'' recalls Patricia Lott, his wife of 32 years. ''I said, 'Fine, you do it.' So when the shirts come home from the cleaners and he doesn't like the way they're ironed, he does it. I don't.'' Even in a world of blow-dried politicians, Lott is known for never having a hair out of place. (''I just spray it once and it stays,'' he says proudly.) Indeed, starched and sprayed, he seems as if he has always been preparing for more public inspection. Now he's getting it. With House Speaker Newt Gingrich engulfed in a storm over ethics, Lott has emerged as the nation's pre-eminent Republican. His conduct, perhaps more than any other factor, could determine the success of President Clinton's second term.

headline.main: Trent Lott and His Fierce Freshmen

docs.abstract: Richard L Berke article on new Senate leadership of Trent Lott; majority leader from Mississippi succeeds embattled Newt Gingrich as nation's pre-eminent Republican, and will have to tame most rambunctious, conservative and independent-minded group of senators in many decades; Lott was House whip and partisan soul mate of Gingrich during 1980's and has reputation as unswerving conservative, but close look at style and record shows he is driven far more by pragmatism and ambition than by ideology; Lott himself observes that strong principles are not much good if they do not produce results; outlook discussed for confrontation this session on hot-button issues such as abortion; brief profiles of several new and veteran conservative lawmakers who could make work for Lott; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Governor Whitman presented a $16.4 billion election year budget last week that brims with modest but politically important initiatives aimed at bolstering her standing with voters beyond her Republican strongholds. There were proposals to offer health insurance to uninsured children, plans to expand urban enterprise zones in the state's cities and promises for more substance-abuse programs for mothers with children.

headline.main: An Election Year Budget, Not One for the Ages

docs.lead_paragraph: THE bell ringer at the Todos Santos church, on a hilltop overlooking the Pacific Ocean at the south end of Mexico's Baja Peninsula, is an old cowboy who chain-smokes on a bench between services. When I pulled into town one Saturday evening in mid-December (behind the wheel of my rather gaseous-smelling rented VW bug), he was getting ready to sound the call to Mass. The sun was setting in a pink wave on the horizon, and soon the little town filled with song emanating from the custard-yellow church. There could be no better welcome to Todos Santos or sweeter reward for making the long, hard, occasionally unnerving trip 1,000 miles south from the Mexican border at Tijuana to the tip of the Baja Peninsula. I'd come part of the way with my brother, John, who lives in Los Angeles. But after five days of exploring the northern Baja from the front seat of his intrepid four-wheel-drive vehicle, he'd turned back at the dusty town of Guerrero Negro, just south of the 28th Parallel, which slices the long, wild peninsula roughly in half. There I'd caught a bus south (for $25, converted at 6.9 pesos to the United States dollar), zigzagging through shadeless forests of cardon cactuses in the Vizcaino Desert and the barren Sierra de la Giganta before finally arriving in La Paz 12 hours later. After an overnight in La Paz, another three-hour bus ride (for $6.50) took me to Cabo San Lucas, where I stayed just long enough to catch a cab to the airport and claim my rental car. (How much easier it would have been had I known, when I made my reservation, that there was an office in town.)

headline.main: Touring the Tip Of Baja California, On Paved Road And Dirt

docs.lead_paragraph: Affirmative Action, the heavyweight plan that was to conquer inequality in the workplace, now lies beaten on the canvas, thoroughly thrashed and humiliated. It has the jelly legs of a tomato can that had the temerity to climb into the ring with an underrated but determined champion, and is now bleeding uncontrollably from both eyes. It wasn't a fair fight. Not close. Many reasons have been given for what happened last Election Day, and about how mere mention of the words ''Affirmative Action'' carry with them enough heat to thoroughly incubate any discourse on race. How mere mention of the concept can stop measured thinking and logic dead in their tracks.

headline.main: Affirmative Action Is KO'd in the Sports Section, Too

docs.abstract: Article by Thad Mumford, essayist and writer, contends that media coverage of black athletes and their million-dollar contracts creates false sense of equality to American public; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a better, fairer world, Wallace Riddle would have been a carpenter. He could build anything, his daughter Donna said. But he was a black man, and in New York City in the late 1940's that meant he could not get a construction job because of the industry's color bar. So he went to work as a bus driver for the city, which had dropped racial barriers to employment, and that changed the fortunes of the Riddle family forever.

headline.main: Black Workers Bear Big Burden As Jobs in Government Dwindle

docs.abstract: State Labor Dept figures show that over 93,000 local, state and Federal jobs have been eliminated in New York City in last five years; city does not record racial composition of people leaving jobs under work force reduction plans, but there is strong evidence that black workers have been hit hardest; way of life in black neighborhoods of southeastern Queens that was built around government work, with assumptions of dependability and equality, is changing; some St Albans residents comment; graph; map; photos (M)
